title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the seasonal changes in global wind patterns between January and July at location 3, such as any of the following:

· Winds come from both the south/southeast and the north/northeast in January and from the south/southeast in July.

· South/southeast and north/northeast winds in the summer and south/southeast winds in the winter.

The response describes the seasonal changes in global wind patterns between January and July at location 3, such as one of the following:

· Winds come from both the south/southeast and the north/northeast in January and from the south/southeast in July.

· South/southeast and north/northeast winds in the summer and south/southeast winds in the winter.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why the days in location 4 have more hours of daylight in June than the days in location 1 have in June, such as any of the following:

· Incoming solar radiation during the days of June/summer in the Northern Hemisphere received at location 4 is higher than in location 1 as a result of the tilt of the Earth and/or the angle of the Sun.

· In the Arctic, the sun never really sets during the June (summer) solstice, so there are almost 24 hours of daylight near the north pole. Closer to the equator, in location 1, there are fewer hours of daylight in June.

The response explains why the days in location 4 have more hours of daylight in June than the days in location 1 have in June, such as one of the following:

· Incoming solar radiation during the days of June/summer in the Northern Hemisphere received at location 4 is higher than in location 1 as a result of the tilt of the Earth and/or the angle of the Sun.

· In the Arctic, the sun never really sets during the June (summer) solstice, so there are almost 24 hours of daylight near the north pole. Closer to the equator, in location 1, there are fewer hours of daylight in June.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how the seasonal wind direction could affect local weather at location 3, such as any of the following:

· The winds in the summer (January) come from the southeast bringing warm (and wet) air from near the equator. The winds in the winter (July) from the ocean keep temperatures mild and relatively warm.

· There is cooler drier air in July from the south and warmer wetter air from the north and east in January.

The response explains how the seasonal wind direction could affect local weather at location 3, such as one of the following:

· The winds in the summer (January) come from the southeast bringing warm (and wet) air from near the equator. The winds in the winter (July) from the ocean keep temperatures mild and relatively warm.

· There is cooler drier air in July from the south and warmer wetter air from the north and east in January.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify the direction toward which the winds in the Northern Hemisphere that blow out of the north and are directed toward southward toward the equator and does not explain why this deflection occurs, such as any of the following:

· The winds are directed to the west/right because of the Coriolis effect.

· The winds deflect to the west/right because of the rotation of the Earth.

The response identifies the direction toward which the winds in the Northern Hemisphere that blow out of the north and are directed toward southward toward the equator and explains why this deflection occurs, such as one of the following:

· The winds are directed to the west/right because of the Coriolis effect.

· The winds deflect to the west/right because of the rotation of the Earth.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the typical change to the weather pattern that happens along the southwestern coast of North America during the years when the winds over the Pacific Ocean weaken or reverse direction, such as any of the following:

· There is an increase in temperature and the amount of rain (in most of Canada/in California and the southwestern United States).

· There are wetter than average conditions along the Gulf Coast.

· There are drier conditions in the Pacific Northwest/the Midwest/the Rocky Mountains.

The response describes the typical change to the weather pattern that happens along the southwestern coast of North America during the years when the winds over the Pacific Ocean weaken or reverse direction, such as one of the following:

· There is an increase in temperature and the amount of rain (in most of Canada/in California and the southwestern United States).

· There are wetter than average conditions along the Gulf Coast.

· There are drier conditions in the Pacific Northwest/the Midwest/the Rocky Mountains.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one economic problem that is a result of the weather change described in part (e), such as any of the following:

· Reduction in fishery production in the Pacific Ocean.

· Property damage from flooding and/or landslides.

· Damage to crops from extreme weather (increased precipitation/snowfall/severe weather events).

descriptions:

title: Part J
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe how the manufacturing of wind turbine blades could increase the ecological footprint of the community, such as any of the following:

· Metals used to manufacture turbine blades must be mined/processed.

· Transportation of materials from mine to manufacturing facilities requires combustion of fossil fuels/heavy equipment/trucks.
